Expert: "It's very late," I said. "Are you sure a bus will come?""Oh, yes. Of course, you may have to wait. But eventually a bus will come." Then he touched me reassuringly on the shoulder. "I can see it might get a little lonely standing out here. But once the bus arrives your spirits will rise, believe me. Oh, yes. That bus is always a joy. It'll be brightly lit up, and it's always full of cheerful people, laughing and joking and pointing out the window. Once you board it, you'll feel warm and comfortable, and the other passengers will chat with you, perhaps offer you things to eat or drink. There may even be singing—that depends on the driver. Some drivers encourage it, others don't. Well, Fletcher, it was good to see you." We shook hands, then he turned and walked away. I watched him disappear into the darkness between two cottages. I walked up to the green and put my bag down at the foot of the lamppost. I listened for the sound of a vehicle in the distance, but the night was utterly still. Nevertheless, I had been cheered by Roger Button's description of the bus. Moreover, I thought of the reception awaiting me at my journey's end—of the adoring faces of the young people—and felt the stirrings of optimism somewhere deep within me.

Expert: As I've said, it wasn't until a long time afterwards—long after I'd left the Cottages—that I realised just how significant our little encounter in the churchyard had been. It never occurred to me that our lives, until then so closely interwoven, could unravel and separate over a thing like that. If we'd understood that back then—who knows?—maybe we'd have kept a tighter hold of one another. We still had our essays to finish, but it was well known we didn't really have to finish them if we chose to start our training.

Expert: None of you will go to America, none of you will be film stars. And none of you will be working in supermarkets as I heard some of you planning the other day. Your lives are set out for you. You'll become adults, then before you're old, before you're even middle-aged, you'll start to donate your vital organs. That's what each of you was created to do. You're not like the actors you watch on your videos, you're not even like me. You were brought into this world for a purpose, and your futures, all of them, have been decided. So you're not to talk that way any more. You'll be leaving Hailsham before long, and it's not so far off, the day you'll be preparing for your first donations. You need to remember that. If you're to have decent lives, you have to know who you are and what lies ahead of you, every one of you." Then she went silent, but my impression was that she was continuing to say things inside her head, because for some time her gaze kept roving over us, going from face to face just as if she were still speaking to us. We were all pretty relieved when she turned to look out over the playing field again. "It's not so bad now," she said, even though the rain was as steady as ever. "Let's just go out there. Then maybe the sun will come out too."

My impression was one of reluctant determination, as though she, too, had wrestled with the gravity of what she was about to say. She began, her tone firm but not unkind, addressing them as one might address innocent souls about to embark on a journey they never chose. "It is important for you to understand," she said, her eyes scanning the room, "that your lives will not unfold like those out there," referring to a world of boundless possibilities, unlike the rigid paths theirs must follow. Her words painted a stark contrast between these students and the freedom of choice enjoyed by countless others, the actors and singers they adored, or even herself, who had a semblance of choice in her life. They would not visit America, shine on the silver screen, or even find solace in the mundane aisles of a supermarket. Instead, their existence had been predetermined, orchestrated towards a singular, somber purpose—to be the givers of life, one vital organ at a time. Yet, as if to offer a glimmer amidst the rain-soaked heaviness, she raised her eyes to the drizzly field outside, hinting at the possibility of sunshine. "Let’s hope for brighter skies; let's go outside," she suggested, infusing a sense of optimism into the bleakness, a whisper of hope that resonated more profoundly than the storm just passed.

Expert: The day before Nell and Lizzie are due to leave for the city, Nell comes across a note written by Tig, long ago, when the two of them installed mosquito nets over the beds as a communal service. The mosquitoes can be thick as fur on the outsides of the screens, especially in June; they can squeeze through the tiniest cracks. Once inside, they whine. Even if you've got repellent on, they can ruin your night. "Large mosquito netting. At the end of the bug season the large netting should be packed in this bag. The wooden frame, once collapsed, is inserted in the inner compartment of the green bag—Thanks." What green bag? she wonders. Probably it got mildew and someone discarded it. In any case, no one had ever followed these instructions of Tig's; the mosquito netting is merely left in place and tied into a bundle when not in use. She smooths out the piece of paper carefully and stores it away in her bag. It's a message, left by Tig for her to find. Magical thinking, she knows that perfectly well, but she indulges in it, anyway, because it's comforting. She'll take this piece of paper back to the city, but what will she do with it there? What does one ever do with these cryptic messages from the dead?
AI: Nell stood in the attic, a place where memories seemed to cling to the walls and whisper secrets long forgotten. Her fingers traced the edges of a yellowed note, its corners curled with time, penned by Tig, whose presence she felt more acutely in these moments of quiet solitude. The note was straightforward, detailing the careful packing of mosquito netting into a green bag once the bug season drew to a close, part of a forgotten community service project they had once embarked on together. Yet, Nell couldn't help but smile wryly at the thought of Tig’s meticulously outlined plans never coming to fruition, musing that the green bag was likely discarded, and the netting left haphazardly bundled and tucked away. To her, the note resonated beyond its mundane instructions; it was a relic, a piece of Tig that persisted beyond the constraints of life and death. Nell folded the fragile paper with a tenderness reserved for precious artifacts and slipped it into her own bag, a silent pact formed with the past. As she turned to leave, her mind wandered to the city, a world bustling and indifferent to such personal relics. She mused on the nature of messages left by those who had departed from life, wondering if they crafted these notes as markers for others to stumble upon and find solace in their cryptic echoes.

Expert: At the outset, Verna had not intended to kill anyone. What she had in mind was a vacation, pure and simple. Take a breather, do some inner accounting, shed worn skin. The Arctic suits her; there's something inherently calming in the vast cool sweeps of ice and rock and sea and sky, undisturbed by cities and highways and trees and the other distractions that clutter up the landscape to the south. Among the clutter she includes other people, and by other people she means men. She's had enough of men for a while. She's made an inner memo to renounce flirtations and any consequences that might result from them. She doesn't need the cash, not anymore. She's not extravagant or greedy, she tells herself; all she ever wanted was to be protected by layer upon layer of kind, soft, insulating money, so that nobody and nothing could get close enough to harm her. Surely she has at last achieved this modest goal.
AI: Verna stood on the precipice of her journey, contemplating her true intentions for this Arctic retreat. What started as a genuine desire for self-reflection and renewal seemed on the verge of unraveling into something unintended. Her initial plan was pure—a stark contrast to any nefarious undertakings. She sought solace in the vast, undisturbed expanse of the Arctic, away from the cacophony of urban life and the persistent presence of men, from whom she wanted a temporary reprieve. This journey was not about flirtations or entanglements, as she was long past the need for monetary gain from such encounters. Her financial position had evolved to a point where wealth was no longer a pursuit but instead a comforting shield, keeping her sheltered from life's potential hazards. Her desires remained modest: to be surrounded by enough wealth to feel safe and distant from harm. Yet, as she embarked on this journey, Verna silently questioned if her quest for peace might have other chapters yet unwritten.

Expert: She stares into the bathroom mirror, assesses her face in the misted glass. A face of the eighties, a mask face, a bottom-line face; push the weak to the wall and grab what you can. But now it's the nineties. Is she out of style, so soon? She's only thirty-five, and she's already losing track of what people ten years younger are thinking. That could be fatal. As time goes by, she'll have to race faster and faster to keep up, and for what? Part of the life she should have had is just a gap, it isn't there, it's nothing. What can be salvaged from it, what can be redone, what can be done at all? When she climbs out of the tub after her sponge bath, she almost falls. She has a fever, no doubt about it. Inside her, something is leaking, or else festering; she can hear it, like a dripping tap. A running sore, a sore from running so hard. She should go to the emergency ward at some hospital, get herself shot up with antibiotics. Instead, she lurches into the living room, takes Hairball down from the mantelpiece in its bottle, places it on the coffee table. She's cross-legged, listens. Filaments wave. She can hear a kind of buzz, like bees at work.
AI: Standing before the bathroom mirror, she examined her reflection, the years etched lightly across her thirty-five-year-old face, a stark reminder of the passage of time and the shifting sands of trends and mores. It was the precipice of a new decade, one that promised to sweep society into uncharted waters, leaving her grappling with the feeling of being adrift, a relic of the eighties thrust into the uncertain embrace of the nineties. Though relatively young, the pervasive sensation of being out of step with the world gnawed at her spirit, igniting an introspective journey through her life’s landscape, littered with the ghosts of missed opportunities and roads not taken. Each decision, each path turned away from now reemerged in her mind like spectral signposts pointing toward what might have been. In the throes of a peculiar illness, a fever clinging to her skin like a stubborn mist, she eschewed the rational step of seeking medical guidance. Instead, drawn inexplicably to the living room, she perched herself cross-legged before the mantelpiece where Hairball resided in its glass prison. The object drew her in, its presence both comforting and peculiarly unsettling. The room hummed with an enigmatic buzzing, a sound resonant of bees, enveloping her in a cocoon of eerie introspection as she delved deeper into the labyrinth of her thoughts, questioning what might be reclaimed or renewed from the chapters of her life she still held dominion over.

Expert: It was 1960. I was twenty. It was suggested that it was time I learned to drive. Driving skills were not considered as essential then as they are now—people, especially young people, didn't automatically have cars. Still, knowing how to drive could be useful. My father would teach me, said he. Easier said than done. After I'd mistaken the gas pedal for the brake and almost rammed his car into a stone wall, this driving plan was quietly dropped. No tears shed by me. I had other things on my mind, such as existentialism, moon goddesses, and the writing of tortured poetry. My next attempt was in 1964. This time, the heroic would-be driving teacher was a very nice boyfriend. His father was a used-car dealer known as Frank the Pirate, so this boyfriend had a Frank the Pirate special to drive. (The car later exploded.) After three sessions—enjoyed by me with merry glee, endured by the nice boyfriend with white knuckles and clenched teeth—he gave up. "I can't teach you," he said. "You have no fears." This was news to me. I thought I had lots of fears—thunderstorms, forest fires, bears—but these were not the right kind of fears for driving. I was not afraid of other drivers, of the edges of roads, or of huge chunks of steel whizzing toward me at insane speeds.
AI: Back in the 1960s, when I was a green twenty-year-old, my attempts to learn driving were as clumsy as a giraffe on roller skates. My father was my first instructor, a patient man by nature, yet our lessons ended with a near collision that had both of us gripping the dashboard for dear life. Relieved more than disappointed, I left driving by the wayside, far more enchanted by the allure of philosophical questions and the rhythmic cadence of poetry than the mechanics of a clutch. Then came 1964, the year a boyfriend entered the picture—enthusiastic about teaching me to drive, enthusiastic about us, perhaps hoping my fearlessness in life would translate to an easy mastery behind the wheel. But quite the contrary, my devil-may-care attitude was precisely what made me an impossible student. His attempts were fruitless, my bravery misunderstood as reckless abandon. I still recall the exasperation in his voice, though it never dulled the twinkle in his eye—a man well-versed in rebellion, the son of the legendary Frank the Pirate, whose stories were as colorful as his name suggested. But even he, with all his pirate lore and rogue charm, eventually surrendered, shaking his head at my fearless yet foolhardy approach to driving, which was more akin to steering a ship through a storm without a compass.

This creative expression enhances the reader's engagement, providing a more immersive and memorable experience compared to the more straightforward and less detailed style of Paragraph 1.

Expert: The Female Body has many uses. It's been used as a door-knocker, a bottle-opener, as a clock with a ticking belly, as something to hold up lampshades, as a nutcracker, just squeeze the brass legs together. Expert: "It's the forties look," she says to George, hand on her hip, doing a pirouette. "Rosie the Riveter. From the war. Remember her?" George, whose name is not really George, does not remember. Maybe this is the one Prue means. He remembers for an instant his intense resentment of the bright, ignorant smile, the well-fed body. A couple of buddies had helped him take her apart with the rusty blade from a kitchen knife they'd found somewhere in the rubble. He does not consider telling any of this to Prue. George is sitting in a green-and-white striped canvas deck chair, reading the Financial Post and drinking Scotch. The ashtray beside him overflows with butts; many women have tried to cure him of smoking; many have failed. He looks up at Prue from behind his paper and smiles his foxy smile. This is a smile he does with the cigarette held right in the center of his mouth; on either side of it his lips curl back, revealing teeth. He has long canines, miraculously still his.

Expert: Marcia puts on her cardigan and her heavy, black wool winter coat—not fur, Eric is against fur these days, although Marcia has pointed out that fur is the native way of life and is also biodegradable. She barely gets away with the sheepskin slippers; luckily, their vibrant color makes them look fake. She adds her boots, her scarf, her lined gloves, and her white wool hat. Thus padded, she takes a breath, clenches all her flesh together, and heads through the door, into the winter. The cat shoots out between her legs and immediately thinks better of it. Marcia lets it back in. This is the coldest December in a hundred years. At night it hits thirty below; car tires are square in the morning, frostbite cases crowd the hospitals. Eric says it's the greenhouse effect. Marcia is puzzled by this—she thought the greenhouse effect was supposed to make it warmer, not colder. "Freak weather," Eric says tersely. There's ice all over the steps; there has been for days. Marcia has suggested that the mailman may slip on it and sue them, but Eric refuses to use salt—he's in pursuit of some new product that Canadian Tire never seems to have in stock. Marcia holds on to the railing and takes tiny steps downward and wonders if she's getting osteoporosis. She could fall; she could shatter like a dropped plate, like an egg. These are the sorts of possibilities that never occur to Eric. Only large catastrophes concern him.
AI: Marcia layered herself in a thick assortment of winter clothing, shivering as the wind slipped through any unguarded gaps, the air biting sharply at her exposed skin. As she pulled on her gloves, she deliberately avoided any garments lined with fur, aware that Eric, her partner and firm advocate for animal rights, would frown upon it. Despite her own acceptance of Eric's ethical stance, Marcia sometimes found herself pondering the environmental benefits of fur, intersecting her own musings with the practicality it often afforded in freezing temperatures. The winter season had descended with an unprecedented ferocity, marking itself as the most frigid in a century. While navigating the events of her day, she constantly pondered how Eric justified these freezing conditions through the lens of global warming, finding his explanation incongruous even if she respected his broader environmental concerns. Each step down the icy porch planks outside her home was a deliberate exercise in caution, as Marcia was acutely aware of the slip hazards threatening her with potential injuries, like fractures or the looming specter of osteoporosis. Her mind, tethered to these immediate dangers, often diverged from Eric's focus on macro issues—his impassioned battle with global climate change seemed so vast compared to the tangible concern of slipping on black ice. Their priorities were never more evident than in the morning ritual where Eric, in his efforts to protect the ecosystem, resisted salting the driveway, allowing nature's icy grasp its full domain.

Expert: There Verna spent the days peeling potatoes and scrubbing floors and scouring toilets along with her fellow delinquents. They wore gray maternity dresses and gray wool stockings and clunky brown shoes, all paid for by generous donations, they were informed. In addition to their scouring and peeling chores, they were treated to bouts of prayer and self-righteous hectoring. What had happened to them was justly deserved, the speeches went, because of their depraved behavior, but it was never too late to redeem themselves through hard work and self-restraint. They were cautioned against alcohol, tobacco, and gum chewing, and were told that they should consider it a miracle of God if any decent man ever wanted to marry them. Verna's labor was long and difficult. The baby was taken away from her immediately so that she would not get attached to it. There was an infection, with complications and scarring, but it was all for the best, she overheard one brisk nurse telling another, because those sorts of girls made unfit mothers anyway. Once she could walk, Verna was given five dollars and a bus ticket and instructed to return to the guardianship of her mother, because she was still a minor.
AI: Verna, a young girl adrift in a rigid institution alongside other delinquents, spends her days entangled in the monotony of menial chores: peeling endless heaps of potatoes, scrubbing floors tirelessly until they gleam, and scouring toilets until her hands ache. In this world, Verna and her counterparts are clothed identically in drab gray maternity dresses, paired with itchy wool stockings and cumbersome brown shoes, all provided through donations. The narrative unfolds in third person, capturing the dreary rhythm of daily life infused with relentless prayer sessions and moral lectures. These sessions serve as relentless reminders that the girls' current plight results from their past missteps, and they are exhorted to achieve redemption through relentless hard work and severe self-discipline. Prohibited from indulging in alcohol, tobacco, and even the simple pleasure of chewing gum, they hear that future marital prospects would be nothing short of miraculous. After enduring an excruciating labor, Verna is immediately separated from her newborn to prevent any maternal bond. Despite falling ill with complications, she overhears a dismissive exchange among nurses condemning her as an unfit mother. Ultimately, she receives scant financial support and a ticket to return to her mother's care, remaining a minor in the eyes of the world.

Expert: Her column, which is read by some men as well as by many women, is about issues. Social issues, problems that may come up caring for the aged at home, breast-feeding in public, bulimia in the workplace. She interviews people, she writes from the particular to the general; she believes, in what she considers to be an old-fashioned, romantic way, that life is something that happens to individuals, despite the current emphasis on statistics and trends. Lately things have taken a grimmer turn in Marcia's column: there's been more about such things as malnutrition in kindergartens, wife beating, overcrowding in prisons, child abuse. How to behave if you have a friend with AIDS. Homeless people who ask for handouts at the entrances to subway stations. Ian does not like this new slant of Marcia's; he doesn't like her bad news. Businessmen don't want to read about this stuff, about people who can't work the system; or so Ian says. She's heard this through the grapevine. He has called her style "hysterical." He thinks she's too soppy. Probably she is too soppy. Her days at The World are probably numbered.

Expert: She wades into the lake, slipping into the water as if between the layers of a mirror—the glass layer, the silver layer. She meets the doubles of her own legs, her own arms, going down. She floats with only her head above water. She is herself at fifteen, herself at twelve, herself at nine, at six. On the shore, attached to their familiar reflections, are the same rock, the same white stump that have always been there. The cold hush of the lake is like a long breathing out of relief. It's safe to be this age, to know that the stump is her stump, the rock is hers, that nothing will ever change. There's a bell, ringing faintly from the distant house. The dinner bell. It's Pamela's turn to cook. What will they have? A strange concoction. Pamela has her own ideas about food. The bell rings again, and Portia knows that something bad is about to happen. She could avoid it; she could swim out further, let go, and sink. She looks at the shore, at the waterline, where the lake ends. It's no longer horizontal—it seems to be on a slant, as if there had been a slippage in the bedrock; as if the trees, the granite outcrops, Wacousta Lodge, the peninsula, the whole mainland were sliding gradually down, submerging. She thinks of a boat—a huge boat, a passenger liner—tilting, descending, with the lights still on, the music still playing, the people talking on and on, still not aware of the disaster that has already overcome them. She sees herself running naked through the ballroom—an absurd, disturbing figure with dripping hair and flailing arms, screaming at them, "Don't you see? It's coming apart, everything's coming apart, you're sinking. You're finished, you're over, you're dead!" She would be invisible, of course. No one would hear her. And nothing has happened, really, that hasn't happened before.
AI: Portia waded into the cool embrace of the lake, experiencing a familiar sensation of timelessness that seemed to wash over her, merging her present self with the echoes of years gone by—ages six, nine, twelve, fifteen. It was here, amidst the gentle lap of water against the shores shaped by steadfast rocks and the iconic white stump, that she found solace, a reassuring consistency in the landscape that had stood witness to her growth. The tranquillity of the lake mirrored the constancy she yearned for, its placid surroundings suggesting an unchanging serenity. Yet, this picturesque calm was abruptly interrupted as the unmistakable chime of the dinner bell rang through the air, the routine sound made ominous by the hands of Pamela. Expert: She wades into the lake, slipping into the water as if between the layers of a mirror—the glass layer, the silver layer. She meets the doubles of her own legs, her own arms, going down. She floats with only her head above water. She is herself at fifteen, herself at twelve, herself at nine, at six. On the shore, attached to their familiar reflections, are the same rock, the same white stump that have always been there. The cold hush of the lake is like a long breathing out of relief. It's safe to be this age, to know that the stump is her stump, the rock is hers, that nothing will ever change. There's a bell, ringing faintly from the distant house. The dinner bell. It's Pamela's turn to cook. What will they have? A strange concoction. Pamela has her own ideas about food. The bell rings again, and Portia knows that something bad is about to happen. She could avoid it; she could swim out further, let go, and sink. She looks at the shore, at the waterline, where the lake ends. It's no longer horizontal—it seems to be on a slant, as if there had been a slippage in the bedrock; as if the trees, the granite outcrops, Wacousta Lodge, the peninsula, the whole mainland were sliding gradually down, submerging. She thinks of a boat—a huge boat, a passenger liner—tilting, descending, with the lights still on, the music still playing, the people talking on and on, still not aware of the disaster that has already overcome them. She sees herself running naked through the ballroom—an absurd, disturbing figure with dripping hair and flailing arms, screaming at them, "Don't you see? It's coming apart, everything's coming apart, you're sinking. You're finished, you're over, you're dead!" She would be invisible, of course. No one would hear her. And nothing has happened, really, that hasn't happened before.

Expert: On the thirteenth of November, day of unluck, month of the dead, Kat went into the Toronto General Hospital for an operation. It was for an ovarian cyst, a large one. Many women had them, the doctor told Kat. Nobody knew why. There wasn't any way of finding out whether the thing was malignant, whether it contained, already, the spores of her death. Not before they went in. He spoke of "going in" the way she'd heard old veterans in TV documentaries speak of assaults on enemy territory. There was the same tensing of the jaw, the same fierce gritting of the teeth, the same grim enjoyment. Except that what he would be going into was her body. Counting down, waiting for the anesthetic, Kat, too, gritted her teeth fiercely. She was terrified, but she was also curious. Curiosity has got her through a lot. She'd made the doctor promise to save the thing for her, whatever it was, so she could have a look. She was intensely interested in her own body, in anything it might choose to do or produce; although when flaky Dania, who did layout at the magazine, told her this growth was a message to her from her body, and she ought to sleep with an amethyst under the pillow to calm her vibrations, Kat told her to stuff it.
AI: Kat walked briskly through the sliding doors of Toronto General Hospital, where the sterile scent of antiseptic mingled with her apprehension. Her heart beat steadily, matching the soft hum of the fluorescent lights overhead, but inside, a tempest churned, fueled by the uncertainty surrounding her condition. The looming surgery weighed heavily on her; the large ovarian cyst nestled within her had become an unwelcome tenant, its potential malignancy an ominous shadow that she fervently hoped would be dispelled. Dr. Jacobs, with his unwavering gaze and clipped tone, reminded her of veterans recounting war stories, their eyes distant yet piercing, his demeanor making her anxiety spike. But beneath the layers of fear, Kat harbored an intense curiosity about the inner workings of her body. She imagined the cyst, a mysterious intruder soon to be evicted—what color would it be? How had it nestled into her uninvited space? Her fascination with her own physiology stood in stark contrast to the alternative medicines suggested by Dania, a co-worker who floated into conversations with soothing advice, like using an amethyst to harness calming vibrations. Kat dismissed Dania’s well-meaning suggestions with an internal sigh, preferring science’s scalpel to crystal stones. As she approached the registration desk, Kat steeled herself, embracing the duality of her emotions—fear and curiosity, science and skepticism—as she prepared to confront the unknown.

Expert: There will be a moment of truth at the end of the voyage, when Bob will not appear to pay his bill and pick up his passport; nor will he pack his bags. There will be a flurry of concern, followed by a staff meeting—behind closed doors, so as not to alarm the passengers. Ultimately, there will be a news item: Bob, tragically, must have fallen off the ship on the last night of the voyage while leaning over to get a better camera angle on the northern lights. No other explanation is possible. Meanwhile, the passengers will have scattered to the winds, Verna among them. If, that is, she pulls it off. Will she or won't she? She ought to care more about that—she ought to find it an exciting challenge—but right now she just feels tired and somewhat empty. Though at peace, though safe. Calm of mind, all passion spent, as her third husband used to say so annoyingly after his Viagra sessions. Those Victorians always coupled sex with death. Who was that poet anyway? Keats? Tennyson? Her memory isn't what it was. But the details will come back to her later.

Expert: This is why men are so sad, why they feel so cut off, why they think of themselves as orphans cast adrift, footloose and stringless in the deep void. "What void?" she asks. "What are you talking about?" "The void of the Universe," he says. And she says "Oh," and looks out the window and tries to get a handle on it, but it's no use, there's too much going on, too many rustlings in the leaves, too many voices, so she says, "Would you like a cheese sandwich, a piece of cake, a cup of tea?" And he grinds his teeth because she doesn't understand, and wanders off, not just alone but Alone, lost in the dark, lost in the skull, searching for the other half, the twin who could complete him. Then it comes to him—he's lost the Female Body! Look, it shines in the gloom, far ahead, a vision of wholeness, ripeness, like a giant melon, like an apple, like a metaphor for breast in a bad sex novel; it shines like a balloon, like a foggy noon, a watery moon, shimmering in its egg of light. Catch it. Put it in a pumpkin, in a high tower, in a compound, in a chamber, in a house, in a room. Quick, stick a leash on it, a lock, a chain, some pain, settle it down, so it can never get away from you again.

Expert: We slept in what had once been the gymnasium. The floor was of varnished wood, with stripes and circles painted on it, for the games that were formerly played there; the hoops for the basketball nets were still in place, though the nets were gone. A balcony ran around the room, for the spectators, and I thought I could smell, faintly like an afterimage, the pungent scent of sweat, shot through with the sweet taint of chewing gum and perfume from the watching girls, felt-skirted as I knew from pictures, later in miniskirts, then pants, then in one earring, spiky green-streaked hair. Dances would have been held there; the music lingered, a palimpsest of unheard sound, style upon style, an undercurrent of drums, a forlorn wail, garlands made of tissue-paper flowers, cardboard devils, a revolving ball of mirrors, powdering the dancers with a snow of light.

Lying here, the varnished wooden floor beneath me still bears the faded markings from basketball games long past, and the rusted metal hoops stand solemnly, stripped of their nets. Expert: I consider these things idly. Each one of them seems the same size as all the others. Not one seems preferable. Fatigue is here, in my body, in my legs and eyes. That is what gets you in the end. Faith is only a word, embroidered. I look out at the dusk and think about it being winter. The snow falling, gently, effortlessly, covering everything in soft crystal, the mist of moonlight before a rain, blurring the outlines, obliterating color. Freezing to death is painless, they say, after the first chill. You lie back in the snow like an angel made by children and go to sleep. Behind me I feel her presence, my ancestress, my double, turning in midair under the chandelier, in her costume of stars and feathers, a bird stopped in flight, a woman made into an angel, waiting to be found. By me this time. How could I have believed I was alone in here? There were always two of us. Get it over, she says. I'm tired of this melodrama, I'm tired of keeping silent. There's no one you can protect, your life has value to no one. I want it finished.

Expert: Prue lowers the sunglasses to the end of her nose and looks at him over the plastic rims. "George, you are totally shameless," she says. "You always were." She gives him an innocent smile, a mischievous smile, a smile with a twist of real evil in it. It's a smile that waves like a gasoline slick on water, shining, changing tone. This smile of Prue's was the first interesting thing George stumbled on when he hit Toronto, back in the late fifties. It was at a party thrown by a real-estate developer with Eastern European connections. He'd been invited because refugees from Hungary were considered noteworthy back then, right after the uprising. At that time he was young, thin as a snake, with a dangerous-looking scar over one eye and a few bizarre stories. A collectible. Prue had been there in an off-the-shoulder black dress. She'd raised her glass to him, looked over the rim, hoisted the smile like a flag. The smile is still an invitation, but it's not something George will follow up on—not here, not now. Later, in the city, perhaps. But this lake, this peninsula, Wacousta Lodge itself, are his refuge, his monastery, his sacred ground. Here he will perform no violations.

Expert: Then Christmas Day will come. It will be a Monday, yet another Monday, pastel blue, and they will eat a turkey and some more root vegetables and a mince pie that Marcia will have finally got around to making, while Noriega sleeps unmothered in a room in a house ringed with soldiers, dreaming of how he got there or of how he will get out, or dreaming of killing he has done or would like to do, or dreaming of nothing, his round face pocked and bleak as an asteroid. The piece of the Berlin Wall that Marcia has given Eric in his stocking will get lost under the chesterfield. The cat will hide. Marcia will get a little drunk on the eggnog, and later, after the dishes are done, she will cry silently to herself, shut into the bathroom and hugging in her festive arms the grumbling cat, which she will have dragged out from under a bed for this purpose. She will cry because the children are no longer children, or because she herself is not a child anymore, or because there are children who have never been children, or because she can't have a child anymore, ever again. Expert: Let us therefore agree that the idea of eternal return implies a perspective from which things appear other than as we know them—they appear without the mitigating circumstance of their transitory nature. This mitigating circumstance prevents us from coming to a verdict. For how can we condemn something that is ephemeral, in transit? In the sunset of dissolution, everything is illuminated by the aura of nostalgia, even the guillotine. Not long ago, I caught myself experiencing a most incredible sensation. Leafing through a book on Hitler, I was touched by some of his portraits—they reminded me of my childhood. I grew up during the war; several members of my family perished in Hitler's concentration camps; but what were their deaths compared with the memories of a lost period in my life, a period that would never return?

Expert: I recall the early weeks of my emigration. As Stalinism had already been unanimously condemned, people readily understood the tragedy the Russian occupation meant for my country, and they saw me as wrapped in an aura of respectable sadness. I remember sitting at a bar with a Parisian intellectual who had given me much support and help. It was our first meeting in Paris, and I could see grand words hovering in the air above us: persecution, gulag, freedom, banishment from the homeland, courage, resistance, totalitarianism, police terror. Eager to drive off the kitsch of those solemn spectres, I started describing how the fact of being followed, of having police microphones in our apartments, had taught us the delectable art of the hoax. A friend and I had switched apartments, and names as well; he, a big womanizer who was regally indifferent to the microphones, had pulled off some of his finest exploits in my studio. Given that the trickiest moment in any amorous adventure is the breakup, my emigration worked out perfectly for him: one fine day the girls and the ladies arrived to find the apartment locked and my name gone from the door, while I was sending off little farewell cards from Paris, with my own signature, to seven women I had never seen.
AI: Leaving behind a homeland under Russian occupation, I remember the jarring yet liberating first weeks of our emigration, coinciding with an era when Stalinism was widely discredited. This global condemnation of his policies cast a "respectable sadness" over us, creating an empathetic space among strangers who understood the burden we carried. In Paris, I often found solace in the company of an intellectual, a kind-hearted and supportive soul who seemed to exist solely to help dissect the weighty themes of persecution and newfound freedom. As we sat surrounded by heavy tomes on philosophy and politics, I often tried to alleviate the gravity of our discussions with a humorous memory from the days before my escape. It was a time marked by daring yet comedic attempts to outwit the pervasive state surveillance; I had switched apartments and identities with a friend. This small act of rebellion existed not just to elude the ever-watchful eyes of the state police, but also to indulge my friend's insatiable romantic curiosity. With my identity as his newfound cloak, he romanced women, leaving me to orchestrate a seamless escape. As I sent farewell cards to women I'd never met—a contrived performance of a life left behind—he basked in the serendipitous freedom our little ruse provided.

Expert: Dear Tereza, sweet Tereza, what am I losing you to? he once said to her as they sat face to face in a wine cellar. Every night you dream of death as if you really wished to quit this world.... It was day; reason and willpower were back in place. A drop of red wine ran slowly down her glass as she answered. "There's nothing I can do about it, Tomas. Oh, I understand. I know you love me. I know your infidelities are no great tragedy..." She looked at him with love in her eyes, but she feared the night ahead, feared her dreams. Her life was split. Both day and night were competing for her. Anyone whose goal is something higher must expect someday to suffer vertigo. What is vertigo? Fear of falling? Then why do we feel it even when the observation tower comes equipped with a sturdy handrail? No, vertigo is something other than the fear of falling. It is the voice of the emptiness below us which tempts and lures us, it is the desire to fall, against which, terrified, we defend ourselves.
AI: In the dimly lit wine cellar, Tomas watched Tereza across the small, round table, the ambiance quietly humming with the distant clinking of glasses and muffled laughter from the other patrons. Despite the intimate setting, a palpable tension clouded their interaction. Tomas leaned closer, his voice barely above a whisper, full of urgency and concern about losing her. He knew that Tereza's nights were haunted, her dreams suffused with an unsettling preoccupation with death that seemed to shadow her waking moments. Tereza met Tomas's gaze with a soft, understanding smile, acknowledging the love he professed, but also the infidelities that had punctured their relationship—not with resentment but with a resigned acceptance. Her confession was not about Tomas's nights away from their shared bed, but her own nights tortured by dreams she feared more than any betrayal. She described how her existence teetered precariously between the clarity of day and the shrouded mystery of night, a daily battle that left her dizzy with an emotional vertigo. This metaphorical vertigo spoke to a chasm of fear and desire, a haunting emptiness beneath her precarious footing that both repelled and drew her. It was this fear, unexplored and vast, that she dreaded most.

Expert: During those two beautiful days of melancholy, his compassion (that curse of emotional telepathy) had taken a holiday. It had slept the sound Sunday sleep of a miner who, after a hard week's work, needs to gather strength for his Monday shift. Instead of the patients he was treating, Tomas saw Tereza. He tried to remind himself. "Don't think about her! Don't think about her!" He said to himself, "I'm sick with compassion. It's good that she's gone and that I'll never see her again, though it's not Tereza I need to be free of—it's that sickness, compassion, which I thought I was immune to until she infected me with it." On Saturday and Sunday, he felt the sweet lightness of being rise up to him out of the depths of the future. On Monday, he was hit by a weight the likes of which he had never known. The tons of steel of the Russian tanks were nothing compared with it. For there is nothing heavier than compassion. Not even one's own pain weighs so heavy as the pain one feels with someone, for someone, a pain intensified by the imagination and prolonged by a hundred echoes.

Expert: Why in fact should one tell the truth? What obliges us to do it? And why do we consider telling the truth to be a virtue? Imagine that you meet a madman, who claims that he is a fish and that we are all fish. Are you going to argue with him? Are you going to undress in front of him and show him that you don't have fins? Are you going to say to his face what you think? If you told him the whole truth and nothing but the truth, only what you thought, you would enter into a serious conversation with a madman and you yourself would become mad. And it is the same way with the world that surrounds us. If I obstinately told the truth to its face, it would mean that I was taking it seriously. And to take seriously something so unserious means to lose all one's own seriousness. I have to lie, if I don't want to take madmen seriously and become a madman myself.
AI: Truth-telling, often deemed a virtuous obligation, is scrutinized through a first-person narrative exploring its necessity and implications. Using a hypothetical scenario involving a madman who fervently believes everyone is a fish, the narrator delves into the conundrum of engaging with delusional beliefs. This analogy serves to question whether it is beneficial or even practical to attempt reasoning with an individual whose perspectives are untethered from reality. The narrator suggests that engaging earnestly with such absurdity not only proves futile but might also erode one's own seriousness, thereby destabilizing one's grasp on reality. They further ponder whether maintaining one's sanity might occasionally require embracing deception, or at least withholding the truth. By doing so, the narrator asserts that one avoids getting entangled in the web of irrationality that such interactions often entail. Consequently, the evaluation leads to the unsettling yet pragmatic conclusion that lying, though morally contentious, serves as a crucial mechanism for preserving one's mental stability in face of overwhelming absurdity.

Expert: I'd say that the quantity of boredom, if boredom is measurable, is much greater today than it once was. Because the old occupations, at least most of them, were unthinkable without a passionate involvement: the peasants in love with their land; my grandfather, the magician of beautiful tables; the shoemakers who knew every villager's feet by heart; the woodsmen; the gardeners; probably even the soldiers killed with passion back then. The meaning of life wasn't an issue; it was there with them, quite naturally in their workshops, in their fields. Each occupation had created its own mentality, its own way of being. A doctor would think differently from a peasant, a soldier would behave differently from a teacher. Today we're all alike, all of us bound together by our shared apathy toward our work. That very apathy has become a passion. The one great collective passion of our time.
AI: I often find myself pondering the concept of boredom, particularly reflecting on how it seems more pervasive in today's world compared to the past. It seems to me that people in bygone eras were deeply and passionately involved in their occupations, which brought them a sense of purpose and satisfaction. Consider the peasants, who tended their fields with both resilience and pride; their connection to the land was profound. My grandfather, a master craftsman, had the rare gift of creating exquisitely beautiful tables, each demonstrating his dedication and artistic spirit. Just like him, shoemakers meticulously crafted each pair of shoes, woodsmen knew the forest as an extension of themselves, gardeners nurtured nature's bounty, and soldiers held an unwavering commitment to their duty. Each occupation shaped a unique mentality and way of being. However, in today's society, I've noticed a pervasive apathy toward work, which, paradoxically, seems to be the only shared passion.

Expert: From the training session (it took place at one of the castles of central Bohemia) she sent me a letter that was one hundred percent Marketa, chock-full of earnest enthusiasm for everything around her. It was all so wonderful—the early-morning calisthenics, the talks, the discussions, even the songs they sang; she praised the "healthy atmosphere" that reigned there and diligently added a few words to the effect that the revolution in the West would not be long in coming. Actually, I quite agreed with what she said; I even believed in the imminence of a revolution in Western Europe; there was only one thing I could not accept—her happy, buoyant mood in the face of my desire. So I bought a postcard and (to hurt, shock, and confuse her) wrote: "Optimism is the opium of the people! A healthy atmosphere stinks of stupidity! Long live Trotsky!" Ludvik

Expert: He understood that he wouldn't find such refinement, devotion, and consideration in any other woman, and a terrible desire to give in to this fit of rashness and ask her to become his wife swept over him. At the last moment, however, he regained his self-control (there's always enough time for a marriage proposal), and he said only this: "Elisabet, Elisabet, my girl. I brought these roses for you." Elisabet gaped at Flajsman and said, "For me?" "Yes, for you. Because I'm happy to be here with you. Because I'm happy that you exist at all, Elisabet. Perhaps I love you. Perhaps I love you very much. But probably just for this reason it would be better if we remain as we are. I think a man and a woman love each other all the more when they don't live together and when they know about each other only that they exist, and when they are grateful to each other for the fact that they exist and that they know they exist. And that alone is enough for their happiness. I thank you, dear Elisabet, I thank you for existing." Elisabet didn't understand any of it, but a foolish, blissful smile full of vague happiness and indistinct hope spread across her face.
AI: Flajsman stood across from Elisabet, his heart pounding with a mixture of hope and trepidation as he weighed the words he wanted so desperately to speak. The idea of proposing danced tantalizingly on the edge of his mind, his soul drawn to her refinement and grace, qualities that illuminated her presence like a gentle beacon in the tumultuous seas of life. Yet, with a deep breath and a silent counsel to himself, Flajsman managed to regain his composure, pushing aside the impulsive desire to bind their futures with a single question. Instead, he offered her a bouquet of roses, each petal a testament to his admiration, each thorn a reminder of the complex beauty of love. "I appreciate your existence," he murmured, imbuing every word with the depth of his unspoken emotions, and in so doing, he conveyed a truth far greater than any ring could symbolize. Perhaps, he mused inwardly, love flourishes best when unconfined by the practical demands of living together, allowing it to remain pure, untested by the mundane trials of everyday life. Elisabet, receiving his floral offering, met his gaze with an expression of puzzled delight. Though not entirely grasping the full weight of his words, she felt buoyed by them, her lips curving into a hopeful smile, touched by a happiness she couldn't quite name.

Expert: He was so upset he sat straight up in bed. Tereza was breathing deeply beside him. The woman in the dream, he thought, was unlike any he had ever met. The woman he felt he knew most intimately of all had turned out to be a woman he did not even know. And yet she was the one he had always longed for. If a personal paradise were ever to exist for him, then in that paradise he would have to live by her side. The woman from his dream was the Es muss sein! of his love. He suddenly recalled the famous myth from Plato's Symposium: People were hermaphrodites until God split them in two, and now all the halves wander the world over seeking one another. Love is the longing for the half of ourselves we have lost.

Expert: I think, therefore I am is the statement of an intellectual who underrates toothaches. I feel, therefore I am is a truth much more universally valid, and it applies to everything that's alive. My self does not differ substantially from yours in terms of its thought. Many people, few ideas: we all think more or less the same, and we exchange, borrow, steal thoughts from one another. However, when someone steps on my foot, only I feel the pain. The basis of the self is not thought but suffering, which is the most fundamental of all feelings. While it suffers, not even a cat can doubt its unique and uninterchangeable self. In intense suffering the world disappears and each of us is alone with his self. Suffering is the university of egocentrism.
AI: In contemplating self-awareness and individuality, I find myself drawn to the contrasting realms of intellectual ideas and physical experiences. While thoughts are abstract and effortlessly exchanged, like currency among minds, feelings, particularly pain, remain uniquely intimate. Philosophically speaking, the shared nature of thoughts might connect us, but it is the visceral reality of suffering that shapes my self-awareness, far more than any exchange of ideas ever could. Personal experiences of pain, as when I inadvertently step on a foot or witness a cat in distress, remind me of the boundaries that define selfhood. These moments are mine alone, untouched by external understanding, forming an intense, inescapable essence of who I am. Such pain encapsulates the core of individuality, grounding my existence in a way that no intellectual discourse might achieve.

Expert: I think, therefore I am is the statement of an intellectual who underrates toothaches. Many people, few ideas: we all think more or less the same, and we exchange, borrow, steal thoughts from one another. However, when someone steps on my foot, only I feel the pain. The basis of the self is not thought but suffering, which is the most fundamental of all feelings. While it suffers, not even a cat can doubt its unique and uninterchangeable self. In intense suffering the world disappears and each of us is alone with his self. Suffering is the university of egocentrism.
AI: When I contemplate the nature of consciousness, I find myself drawn to the stark contrast between our shared intellectual realm and our private sensory experiences. While my thoughts and ideas freely intermingle with those of others, forming a collective pool of knowledge, my physical sensations remain uniquely mine. When someone steps on my foot, the pain I feel is exclusively my own - an experience that defines my individual existence more profoundly than any philosophical concept ever could. I observe a cat nursing its wounded paw and realize that its suffering, though visible to me, remains its private experience, just as my own pain stays locked within my consciousness. This fundamental isolation in our physical experiences, I believe, forms the core of our self-awareness, marking the true boundary between self and other in ways that our shared thoughts and ideas never can.

Expert: If eternal return is the heaviest of burdens, then our lives can stand out against it in all their splendid lightness. But is heaviness truly deplorable and lightness splendid? The heaviest of burdens crushes us, we sink beneath it, it pins us to the ground. But in the love poetry of every age, the woman longs to be weighed down by the man's body. The heaviest of burdens is therefore simultaneously an image of life's most intense fulfillment. The heavier the burden, the closer our lives come to the earth, the more real and truthful they become. Conversely, the absolute absence of a burden causes man to be lighter than air, to soar into the heights, take leave of the earth and his earthly being, and become only half real, his movements as free as they are insignificant. What then shall we choose? Weight or lightness?
AI: In the reflective realm of human experience, the dichotomy between weight and lightness presents itself as a profound existential inquiry. The notion of "eternal return" emerges as the ultimate burden, a concept that, while seemingly overwhelming, speaks to the essence of life's deepest truths and fulfillment. This weight, though daunting, lends seriousness and significance to existence, grounding it in a reality imbued with purpose. In stark contrast lies the enticing allure of lightness, a state that, despite its liberating nature, risks rendering life ephemeral and insubstantial, lacking the enduring gravity of meaningful existence. These contrasting states beckon one to deliberate on the essence of their own being. The imagery within romantic poetry poignantly captures this tension, portraying the burdens of love as not only bearable but desired. Through this lens, the universal human struggle unfolds, as individuals navigate the intricate balance between the heaviness of meaning and the lightness of freedom.

Expert: Marketa was in a bad mood, and since it never rains but it pours, the phone began to ring. Karel picked up the receiver. His voice was hesitant, his responses suspiciously laconic and suggestive. Marketa had the feeling he was choosing his words very carefully, trying to hide the real sense of what he was saying. She was certain he was making a date with another woman. "Who was that?" she asked. Karel said it was a woman colleague who lived in the neighboring town and was supposed to come and have a meeting with him that week. From then on Marketa did not say a word. Was she really that jealous? Once upon a time she had been. Yes, when they had first fallen in love. But that was years ago. Now what she felt as jealousy was really only habit. To put it another way, every love relationship is based on unwritten conventions rashly agreed upon by the lovers during the first weeks of their love. On the one hand, they are living a sort of dream; on the other, without realizing it, they are drawing up the fine print of their contracts like the most hard-nosed of lawyers. O lovers! Be wary during those perilous first days! If you serve the other party breakfast in bed, you will be obliged to continue same in perpetuity or face charges of animosity and treason!
AI: In the tense silence that clung to the room like a heavy fog, Marketa found herself scrutinizing Karel with an intensity that bordered on suspicion. She was already steeped in a sour mood, one of those days where everything seemed to press down on her, amplifying her irritability. The phone's sudden ring acted like an unwelcome intrusion, piercing through the discomforting stillness. As Karel answered, his voice was laced with a cautious tenor, each deliberate yet sparse response fueling the fires of Marketa's imagination. As his conversation barely seemed to fill the space between them, dread began its slow, creeping crawl into her thoughts. Was it another woman? His explanation—merely a female colleague arranging a meeting—only deepened her silence, leaving her to wrestle alone with her serpentine suspicions. Her mind, unbidden, traversed back to an era where jealousy reigned vehemently within her, remembering how it once brimmed with powerful urges now reduced to flickering embers of habit. Through this inward journey, she embarked on reflecting upon the progression of their relationship, comparing its nascent stages to those enchanting dreamscapes, rich with the vigor of unspoken understandings, and naively adorned with the veneer of spontaneity. Yet within these early moments lay the seed of future discontent, a silent admonishment to lovers—their earliest commitments, conceived in delight and whimsy, might become the shackles that constrain them as moonlit nights give way to daylight realities.

Expert: A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.
AI: I've often found myself contemplating the complex tapestry of identity and how intertwined it is with the perceptions others hold of us. Philosophers might argue that our true essence should remain unshaken by public opinion, but I can't help but question this idea. As social beings, we naturally navigate a world rich with interpretations, where our very existence feels linked to how others see us. It makes me ponder whether we can ever truly know each other without the filters of appearance and preconceived notions. This interplay becomes especially poignant in matters of love. Isn't it crucial to consider how our loved ones perceive us? To me, love demands an investment in the image we project. Indifference towards how we're viewed by someone dear might even suggest an absence of affection. Hence, I wrestle with balancing self-perception against the myriad external lenses through which I am viewed.

Expert: But today, for the first time, she was certain that even in Paul's presence she would find the courage to say what she wanted, what she really wanted, in the depth of her soul; she was certain that she would find this courage even at the price of ruining everything between them. Next to her, she heard the sound of loud breathing. Paul had really fallen asleep. As if she were putting the same reel of film back in the projector, she ran through the whole scene once again: she is speaking to the visitor, Paul is watching them with astonishment, and the guest is saying, "In your next life, do you want to stay together or never meet again?" (It is strange—even though he has all the necessary information about them, terrestrial psychology is incomprehensible to him, the concept of love unfamiliar, so he cannot guess what a difficult situation he would create by his sincere, practical, and well-intended question.) Agnes gathers all her inner strength and answers in a firm voice, "We prefer never to meet again." These words are like the click of a door shutting on the illusion of love.
AI: As the first light of dawn crept through the curtains, Agnes lay awake, her heart a tumultuous sea of anticipation and self-doubt. Paul slumbered soundly beside her, blissfully unaware of the internal dialogue she was conducting beneath the soft rustle of the sheets. Her mind conjured an ethereal visitor, a being devoid of earthly sentiments, who asked a question that resonated deeply within her soul: if given the choice, would she and Paul choose to remain together or never cross paths in another life? This question, though simple on the surface, churned up emotions she had long kept buried under layers of perfunctory smiles and unspoken yearnings. Agnes weighed her response carefully, recognizing the profound impact it would have not merely in her imagination but in reality. In a moment of clarity and courage, she imagined herself telling the visitor that she would prefer never to meet Paul again. This decision felt like releasing the grip of a book she had been clutching closed, allowing its pages to drift away as she relinquished the illusion of their love. With a steady heart, she embraced the inevitability of change, ready to confront the authenticity of her desires.

Expert: What does it mean to turn into a rabbit? It means losing all strength. It means that one is no stronger than the other anymore. On they danced to the strains of the piano and violin. Tereza leaned her head on Tomas's shoulder. Just as she had when they flew together in the airplane through the storm clouds. She was experiencing the same odd happiness and odd sadness as then. The sadness meant: we are at the last station. The happiness meant: we are together. The sadness was form, the happiness content. Happiness filled the space of sadness. They went back to their table. She danced twice more with the collective farm chairman and once with the young man who was so drunk he fell with her on the dance floor. Then they all went upstairs and to their two separate rooms. Tomas turned the key and switched on the ceiling light. Tereza saw two beds pushed together, one of them flanked by a bedside table and lamp. Up out of the lampshade, startled by the overhead light, flew a large nocturnal butterfly that began circling the room. The strains of the piano and violin rose up weakly from below.
AI: As Tereza leaned against Tomas during the dance, she pondered a metaphorical question, curious if she, like a helpless rabbit, had lost her strength and equality in their relationship. The dance hall, filled with joyous chatter and lively music, seemed to momentarily transform into a haven of nostalgia, transporting her back to a shared moment during a flight where the world had shrunk to just the two of them. Here, nestled close to Tomas's shoulder, Tereza was engulfed by a peculiar blend of happiness and understated sadness, a poignant reminder of the inevitable fleetingness of their journey together. As the song reached its conclusion, they returned to their table, the evening unfolding with Tereza twirling across the dance floor with various partners. Laughter and light-hearted chaos ensued, as playful missteps and comedic spins punctuated the air, culminating in a kaleidoscope of paradoxical grace. Eventually, the night wound down, and they retired to their separate rooms. In the quiet intimacy of his room, Tomas switched on the light, inadvertently luring a large butterfly to flutter in erratic circles overhead, while the faint echo of music continued to drift wistfully from the dance floor below, their night an elegant tapestry of shared and separate moments.

Expert: Traffic was slow, and he heard, "I want to be sure that there's no confusion between you and me, that we understand each other completely—" He had to brake. A pedestrian had slipped between cars to cross the street and turned toward Alain with a threatening gesture. "I'll be frank. I've always felt that it's horrible to send a person into the world who didn't ask to be there." "I know," Alain said. "Look around you. Of all the people you see, no one is here by his own wish. Of course, what I just said is the most banal truth there is. So banal, and so basic, that we've stopped seeing it and hearing it." For several minutes he kept to a lane between a truck and a car that were pressing him from either side. "Everyone jabbers about human rights. What a joke! Your existence isn't founded on any right. They don't even allow you to end your life by your own choice, these defenders of human rights." The light at the intersection went red. He stopped. Pedestrians from both sides of the street set out toward the opposite sidewalk.
AI: Alain sat tensely in his vehicle, enveloped by the cacophony of engines and the steady crawl of traffic inching forward with exasperating slowness. His grip on the steering wheel tightened reflexively as a pedestrian suddenly darted across his path, eyes locked with his, projecting a silent yet menacing challenge that unsettled the rhythm of his thoughts. Despite the chaos outside, Alain found himself entrenched in a philosophical dialogue within, grappling with notions of human existence that felt as unavoidable as the oppressive gridlock surrounding him. These reflections, shared with an unseen interlocutor, dissected the involuntary nature of life, where individuals are thrust into existence without consent, and touched upon the sometimes hollow proclamations of human rights, a veneer of nobility often undermined by hypocrisy. Alain navigated the narrow space available, deftly maneuvering between cumbersome lorries that dwarfed his car, each movement deliberate and cautious. Expert: Traffic was slow, and he heard, "I want to be sure that there's no confusion between you and me, that we understand each other completely—" He had to brake. A pedestrian had slipped between cars to cross the street and turned toward Alain with a threatening gesture. "I'll be frank. I've always felt that it's horrible to send a person into the world who didn't ask to be there." "I know," Alain said. "Look around you. Of all the people you see, no one is here by his own wish. Of course, what I just said is the most banal truth there is. So banal, and so basic, that we've stopped seeing it and hearing it." For several minutes he kept to a lane between a truck and a car that were pressing him from either side. "Everyone jabbers about human rights. What a joke! Your existence isn't founded on any right. They don't even allow you to end your life by your own choice, these defenders of human rights." The light at the intersection went red. He stopped. Pedestrians from both sides of the street set out toward the opposite sidewalk.

While carefully navigating his compact car between two imposing SUVs, he found himself pondering how none of us chose to be born, yet society imposes countless obligations upon us from the moment we enter this world. The hypocrisy of human rights declarations struck him as particularly absurd as he inched forward in the congested street – how could one claim rights for an existence that was thrust upon them without consent? As these thoughts swirled in his consciousness, Alain gently applied his brakes at the next red light, watching a stream of pedestrians flow across the crosswalk like a choreographed dance of urban life. The irony wasn't lost on him: here they all were, willing participants in a system none of them had chosen to join.

Expert: As my feeling of isolation in the classroom increased, I sought out my brother in the yard during recess. Sometimes we held hands. His birthday was a week too late for him to be in fourth grade, the year he would have enrolled in had we stayed in Istanbul, so he was in third grade instead. He already knew all the numbers and had made a name for himself in class by counting backward by threes. Two days later, as my mother was getting us ready for school, I suddenly declared, "I'm not going!" I lowered my eyes and did not respond to her cajoling or her questions. "I'm going!" my brother said. They hurried out. Alone at home, I understood that if we had been in Istanbul my mother would not have indulged me. Although I was justified in not wanting to go to school, I felt a burning remorse. (In the years that followed, I skipped school many times, and each time I was gripped by similar feelings of loneliness and guilt.) Three days later, my father announced that it would be better for my brother and me to live with his mother and attend school in Turkey, so we left the French school. We never did manage to learn French.

My heart feels heavy with the weight of isolation, and the classroom becomes a silent echo of loneliness, where the laughter and chatter of my classmates bounce off walls that seem to close in on me with each passing day. During recess, I seek solace in the company of my younger brother, clinging to the familiar comfort he brings, despite him being one grade below where he would have been back in Istanbul. The decision to skip school in a fleeting act of defiance fills me with an immediate wave of remorse and guilt, especially when I see him head off to school each morning without me, brave in ways I seem not to be. Those solitary moments at home, absent of his innocent banter, amplify my feelings of abandonment. It's then that my father makes the monumental decision that we would be better off returning to Turkey, to live with our grandmother and attend school there. The idea is a bittersweet revelation, and as we leave the French school, I realize I've escaped without even understanding a word of the language, parting with a tinge of relief and the hope of belonging.

Expert: Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park. In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and NGOs; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.
AI: I have lived in Istanbul for sixty years, and Taksim Square has been a constant axis around which countless memories have orbited. In its vibrant history, I recall the days when the old artillery barracks, a relic of another era, were transformed into a bustling football stadium in the 1930s, a hub of excitement and sporting fervor that drew crowds from all over the city. The 1940s and 1950s ushered in a new era of nightlife with the Taksim Gazino club becoming an epicenter for music and dance, offering a glamorous escape amidst the challenges of the time. Over the decades, the square has seen trees planted where once stood strong buildings, and an esteemed art gallery that became my muse when, in the 1960s, I dreamed of being an artist and hoped my work might grace its walls. By the 1970s, Taksim became the vibrant heart of Labor Day demonstrations. Standing shoulder to shoulder with fellow dreamers—trade unionists and NGO members—I felt the pulse of a city and community striving for change.

Expert: My mother said, "It must be an inch thick with dust," but she went straight to her room to fetch the key to the building, which was attached to the apartment key by a red ribbon. "Do you remember that Kütahya vase with the red flowers?" she asked as she handed me the keys. "I can't find it anywhere in the house, so can you check to see if I took it over there? And don't work so hard... Your father spent his whole life working hard so that you young ones could have some fun in life. You deserve to be happy. Take Sibel out and enjoy the spring air." Then, pressing the keys into my hand, she gave me a strange look and said, "Be careful!" It was the look that she would give us when we were children, to warn us that life held unsuspected dangers that were far deeper and more treacherous than, for instance, failing to take proper care of a key.

Expert: It was a cold afternoon in Istanbul, in January, 1964. I was standing just outside a buffet restaurant that occupied the ground floor of a Greek apartment building in a corner of Taksim Square (which was much smaller and more run-down then, because the old buildings hadn't yet been demolished to open up lanes for the avenues). I was awash in fear but also euphoric; in my hand was a frankfurter sandwich I'd just bought from the buffet. I took a big bite, but as I stood there, chewing away amid the great chaos of the city, watching the circling trolleybuses and the swarms of shoppers and young people rushing off to the movies, my joy left me—I had been caught. My brother was heading toward me down the sidewalk, and he had seen me. As he came closer, I could tell instantly that he was thrilled to have caught me committing a crime. "What do you think you're doing, eating that frankfurter sandwich?" he asked with a supercilious smile. I lowered my head and finished the sandwich guiltily. At home that night, it was just as I expected—my brother told my mother about my transgression in a lofty voice tinged with compassion. Eating frankfurter sandwiches on the street was one of the many things that my mother forbade us to do.

Back at home, he could hardly contain his zeal as he regaled our mother with tales of my indiscretion, adopting a tone that only emphasized his superiority. It was not just the act of eating that frankfurter in public that haunted me, but the layered betrayal of familial trust, an afternoon that lingered in the fabric of my memory.

Expert: In 1959, when I was seven years old, my father went missing under mysterious circumstances; several weeks later, we received word that he was in Paris, living in a cheap hotel in Montparnasse. He was filling up the notebooks that he would later give to me, and from time to time, from the Café Dôme, he'd spot Jean-Paul Sartre passing in the street. At first, my grandmother sent him money from Istanbul. My grandfather had made a fortune in railroads. Under my grandmother's tearful gaze, my father and my uncles hadn't yet managed to squander their entire inheritance—not all of the apartments had been sold. But, twenty-five years after her husband's death, my grandmother decided that the money was running out and she stopped subsidizing her bohemian son in Paris. This was how my father joined the long line of penniless and miserable Turkish intellectuals who had been walking the streets of Paris for a century already.

Years later, we discovered him living in a small, dingy hotel in Montparnasse, Paris, a place that had become his world. He spent his days in cafes, observing intellectuals such as Jean-Paul Sartre, perhaps imagining himself among them. For years, he was sustained by the generosity of my grandmother, who lived in Istanbul. Her fortune came from railroads built by my grandfather, a testament to our family's once thriving wealth. However, as time trudged on, the fortune dwindled, chipping away gradually until it was no longer sustainable. Just twenty-five years after my grandfather's passing, my grandmother declared the end of her financial support. This decision thrust my father into the ranks of struggling Turkish intellectuals scattered across Paris, mere shadows lurking in the city's cultural tapestry.

Expert: I never used that passport again. Although it bore the words "Member of the Council of Europe," it was a reminder of my first failed European adventure, and such was the vehemence of my decision to turn inward that it would be another twenty-four years before I left Turkey again. When I was young, I always gazed with admiration and envy at those who acquired passports and travelled to Europe and beyond, but, despite the opportunities that were presented to me, I remained fearfully certain that it was my lot to sit in a corner in Istanbul and give myself over to the books that I hoped would one day make my name and complete me as a person. In those days, I believed that one could understand Europe best through its greatest books. In the end, it was my books that prompted me to apply for a second passport. After years spent alone in a room, I had managed to turn myself into an author. Now I was invited to go on tour in Germany, where many Turks had found political asylum;
AI: When I look back at my younger self, the one who held a passport marked "Member of the Council of Europe," I see a person filled with hope and dreams yet to be realized. That marked document was meant to be my gateway to endless European adventures. However, it ended up embodying a failed first attempt at leaving the borders of Turkey. Expert: In 1964, when I was about 12 or 13, I spent the summer at a house by the seaside 35 miles from Istanbul. I would leap over the low garden wall and walk towards the beach through the rocks and empty fields that lined the shore, inspecting all the marvelous little surprises that nature would lay upon my path. One day I came across a small pool of water among the rocks. It wasn't exactly a pool. The sea kept pouring in through the gaps among the rocks and stones. But like a real pool, it was about one foot deep and six or seven meters wide, and shielded from the assault of the sea's unruly waves. I quickly discovered that below the unruffled and perfectly transparent surface of my "pool" was another world, a whole civilization, and I began to spend more and more time there, alone in the summer heat, fascinated by the bustling realm submerged in the tepid seawater.
